facts.text: Six writ petitions filed under Art. 32 challenging validity of Constitution (17th Amendment) Act, 1964.
Petitioners affected by one or other of Acts added to 9th Schedule by impugned Act.
Interveners similarly affected by other Acts added to 9th Schedule.
Impugned Act amends Art. 31A by adding proviso to cl. (1) and substituting sub-cl. (a) of cl. (2); adds 44 entries to 9th Schedule.
Articles 31A and 31B added by Constitution (1st Amendment) Act, 1951 with retrospective effect to protect agrarian reform laws challenged as violating Part III.
Art. 31A amended by Constitution (4th Amendment) Act, 1955 to widen scope of agrarian reform protection.
Kerala Agrarian Relations Act, 1961 struck down by Supreme Court on December 5, 1961 in Karimbil Kunhikoman v. State of Kerala.
Madras Land Reforms (Fixation of Ceiling on Land) Act, 1961 declared invalid by Supreme Court on March 9, 1964 in A. P. Krishnaswami Naidu v. State of Madras.
Rajasthan Tenancy Act, 1955 and Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceiling on Holdings) Act, 1961 declared invalid.
High Courts in Bihar, UP, MP faced challenges to agrarian laws; Patna HC struck down Bihar law, Allahabad and Nagpur upheld others.

legal_issues.text: Whether impugned 17th Amendment Act requires ratification by half the States under proviso to Art. 368 as it affects powers under Art. 226 indirectly by amending Part III.
Whether Parliament has power under Art. 368 to amend provisions in Part III including fundamental rights, or is limited by Art. 13(2).
Whether impugned Act is legislation on land under Entry 18 List II, beyond Parliament's competence.
Whether retrospective validation of struck-down Acts by adding to 9th Schedule is unconstitutional.

petitioner_arguments.text: Amendment of Part III affects High Court powers under Art. 226, attracting proviso to Art. 368 requiring State ratification.
Impugned Act is land legislation within State List, beyond Parliament's power.
Act sets aside court decisions declaring Acts invalid, unconstitutional.
Power to amend under Art. 368 does not include taking away fundamental rights.

petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sri Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned Act amends Constitution under substantive part of Art. 368; effect on Art. 226 incidental.
Not land legislation but validates State agrarian laws by constitutional amendment.
Retrospective validation constitutional; legislatures can validate prospectively and retrospectively.

court_reasoning.text: Pith and substance of impugned Act is amendment of Constitution to facilitate agrarian reform by protecting State laws via Arts. 31A, 31B and 9th Schedule; effect on Art. 226 indirect and insignificant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso applies only if amendment seeks to change Art. 226 directly.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 368 empowers amendment of all provisions including Part III without proviso unless specified; Art. 13(2) 'law' excludes constitutional amendments under constituent power.
Not land legislation but constitutional amendment validating State laws; Parliament competent.
Retrospective exercise of constituent power valid notwithstanding prior court judgments.
No need to reconsider Sankari Prasad; stare decisis applies absent compelling reasons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prior decision followed in many cases.

court_reasoning.text: Hidayatullah J.: Agrees on Art. 226 not changed directly; reserves opinion on Art. 13(2) scope.
Mudholkar J.: Agrees petitions fail; reserves opinion on Art. 13(2); amendment is legislative act subject to judicial review.

holdings.text: 17th Amendment Act valid; does not attract proviso to Art. 368.
Parliament has power under Art. 368 to amend Part III; Art. 13(2) does not apply to constitutional amendments (majority view).

precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld 1st Amendment; Art. 13(2) excludes amendments; no change to Art. 226.

outcome.summary: Writ petitions challenging validity of Constitution (17th Amendment) Act, 1964 dismissed; Act held constitutionally valid.

key_quotes.text: "in considering the constitutional validity of the impugned Act, it would be relevant to inquire what the pith and substance of the impugned Act is."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies pith and substance test to determine if proviso to Art. 368 applies.

key_quotes.text: "Art. 13(2) does not affect amendments made under Art. 368."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reaffirms Sankari Prasad on scope of amendment power over fundamental rights.

key_quotes.text: "the power to amend in the context is a very wide power and it cannot be controlled by the literal dictionary meaning of the word amend."
key_quotes.speaker: court
